title: Alex Newhouse
text:
I am a PhD candidate in Political Science at the University of Colorado Boulder, specializing in the intersection of technology, political violence, and extremism. My research focuses on measuring online-offline relationships in political violence using advanced computational methods including machine learning, natural language processing, and social network analysis.
Currently, I serve as a Senior Non-Resident Fellow at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, where I previously held leadership roles at the Center on Terrorism, Extremism, and Counterterrorism (CTEC). My work bridges academic research with real-world applications, having served as an investigative consultant for the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack and collaborated extensively with technology companies on content moderation and safety initiatives.

title: Alex Newhouse

Research Interests

Political Violence & Extremism: Online-offline dynamics of radicalization and mobilization
Computational Social Science: Machine learning and NLP applications to political phenomena

Technology & Society: Digital platforms, gaming environments, and extremist recruitment
Causal Inference: Time-series analysis of political and social processes
Visual Politics: Media framing and partisan polarization in news coverage

title: Alex Newhouse
text:
Current Projects
Dissertation Research: Examining how online extremist communities translate digital engagement into offline political violence through computational analysis of social media data and network structures.
COVID-19 Media Framing: Investigating partisan differences in visual and textual framing of pandemic coverage across U.S. news outlets (with Andrew Q. Philips and Komal P. Kaur).
Gaming & Extremism: Studying recruitment and radicalization processes within digital gaming environments, including partnerships with major gaming platforms for harm mitigation.

title: Alex Newhouse
text:
Teaching
I have taught courses on digital extremism and online radicalization at both Middlebury College and MIIS, and currently serve as a teaching assistant for courses in comparative politics, international relations, and quantitative methods at CU Boulder.

For collaboration inquiries or media requests, please reach out via email.

title: Teaching
text: I believe in making complex political science concepts accessible through hands-on learning and real-world applications. My teaching emphasizes the intersection of theory and practice, particularly in quantitative methods and comparative politics, drawing from my research experience in computational social science and political violence.

Apply computational methods to political phenomena
Critically evaluate digital media and online communities
Understand the methodological challenges of studying sensitive political topics
Connect theoretical frameworks to empirical analysis

title: Intro to Greek Notation and Univariate Descrpitive Statistics
text:
For most people, one of the most challenging parts about learning data analysis and quantitative methods is getting used to all of the complicated notation. This is perfectly understandable: math notation uses Greek (literally a different language than English) and combines it with math!
While the learning curve is steep, you will eventually get more comfortable consuming Greek notation. In this tutorial, I‚Äôll walk through some of the most common symbols you‚Äôll encounter and illustrate them with the univariate descriptive statistics that you‚Äôll need to know.

title: Intro to Greek Notation and Univariate Descrpitive Statistics
text:
For most people, one of the most challenging parts about learning data analysis and quantitative methods is getting used to all of the complicated notation. This is perfectly understandable: math notation uses Greek (literally a different language than English) and combines it with math!
While the learning curve is steep, you will eventually get more comfortable consuming Greek notation. In this tutorial, I‚Äôll walk through some of the most common symbols you‚Äôll encounter and illustrate them with the univariate descriptive statistics that you‚Äôll need to know.

title: Intro to Greek Notation and Univariate Descrpitive Statistics
section: Mean (a.k.a first population moment) (a.k.a expected value)
text:
Mean (a.k.a first population moment) (a.k.a expected value)
Mean, which is one measure of the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù or central tendency of a set of values, is calculated by summing all of your values and dividing by the total number of values that you have. This should be pretty familiar for you, you likely know intuitively that the average of \(1 + 2 + 3 = 2\).
Shown below is how this looks in code. I first generate 500 random values and store them as a column in a dataframe. Then, I print the mean of that column. Last, I create a histogram of the values and show the mean wtih a red line.

library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.3.0
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.1.0     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

set.seed(1234)
# simulate 500 values and store as a vector in a dataframe
df <- data.frame(x = rnorm(500))

# print the mean
mean(df$x)

[1] 0.001838821

# graph the histogram and show the mean line (in red)
df %>% 
    ggplot() + 
    geom_histogram(aes(x = x)) + 
    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = mean(x)), color = "red")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.









We simulated data from the ‚Äústandard normal‚Äù distribution (don‚Äôt worry about what that means yet), which by definition has a mean of 0‚Äìand you can see that we are finding a mean of close to zero! And, indeed, if we do the basic ‚Äúadd up all the values and divide by the number of values‚Äù, you‚Äôll get the same value:

sum_x = sum(df$x)
sum_x / length(df$x)

[1] 0.001838821


What does this look like in Greek notation? Let‚Äôs take a look:
\[\mathbb{E}[X] = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n X_i}{n}\]
Despite the fact that you‚Äôre probably comfortable with the concept of mean, there are a lot of symbols here to describe that concept. It can be daunting! But we can break it down and show that it really isn‚Äôt that bad.
\(\mathbb{E}[X]\) is how we symbolize ‚ÄúExpected Value of X‚Äù; in this case, we‚Äôre using X to refer to our whole set of values (the vector containing all of the numbers that we want to find the mean of). Expected value, remember, just means ‚Äúmean‚Äù.
\(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i\) symbolizes a summation. The sigma \(\sum\) is the greek symbol for ‚Äúadd all of the elements together‚Äù. The \(i\) below the sigma indicates that we‚Äôre going to start at the first element of our data. The \(n\) above the sigma indicates that we‚Äôre going to use all of the data up to the last value. \(X_i\) refers to the \(i\)-th element of X, our vector holding all of the values that we want to average.
To put it together, we‚Äôre summing every value from \(X_1\) to \(X_n\), and then we‚Äôre dividing that by \(n\). In this case, our \(X\) vector is the data that we simulated, and we‚Äôre going to go from \(X_1\) to \(X_{500}\) (since we created 500 values in our original code).

title: Intro to Greek Notation and Univariate Descrpitive Statistics
text:
Variance
Let‚Äôs turn to another important descriptive statistic, variance. This measures the ‚Äúspread‚Äù, or ‚Äúdispersion‚Äù, of your data around the mean. Think how long the tails on the left and right of the mean are.
Finding variance in code is easy:

var(df$x)

[1] 1.07084


What does a higher or lower variance actually mean? Let‚Äôs investigate. We‚Äôre going to create two new vectors/columns: a high variance one (var = 4) and a low variance one (var = .25). Note: the code we use to generate this asks for standard deviation, which is just the square root of the variance.
After adding a ‚Äúhigh_var‚Äù and a ‚Äúlow_var‚Äù column to our data frame, we then create a histogram showing the different columns on the same graph. Our high-variance data is shown in blue, our original data is shown in orange, and our low-variance data is shown in green. What do you notice?

df <- df %>% 
    mutate(high_var = rnorm(500, mean = 0, sd = 2)) %>% 
    mutate(low_var = rnorm(500, mean = 0, sd = .5))

df %>% 
    ggplot() + 
    geom_histogram(aes(x = high_var), fill = "navy", alpha = .5) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = low_var), fill = "darkgreen", alpha = .5) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = x), fill = "orange") + 
    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = mean(x)), color = "red")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.









Variance in Greek notation is pretty similar to that of the mean‚Äìin fact, mean and variance are linked mathematically, too! The variance equation is depicted by:
\[\text{Var(X)} = \sigma^2 = s^2 = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i - \mu)^2}{n-1}\]
Let‚Äôs walk through it piece by piece. First, \(\text{Var(X)}, \sigma^2, \text{and } s^2\) are all different ways of saying ‚Äúvariance of X‚Äù. Second, now we have a slightly different summation than what‚Äôs in the equation for mean. \(\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i - \mu)^2\) is depicting how we are summing (\(\sum\)) from our first element (\(i=1\)) to our \(n\)-th element for the value \((X_i - \mu)^2\), where \(\mu\) is simply the mean of \(X\). Intuitively, this is finding the sum of all of the distances (squared) between a single value \(X_i\) and the mean of all of the values. Last, we divide that summed value by \(n-1\).
Note that variance includes mean as part of its equation. You can literally take the mean we calculated above and plug it into this function and find the right value! Let‚Äôs see how that looks:

var(df$x)

[1] 1.07084

mean_x <- mean(df$x)
sum_squared_distance <- sum((df$x - mean_x)^2)
var_calc = sum_squared_distance/(length(df$x)-1)
var_calc

[1] 1.07084


So the variance of a sample is a function of the mean of that sample.
